title: Personal Bank Accounts in Cyprus
content:
Opening a Personal Bank Account in Cyprus

Moving to Cyprus requires setting up your financial life, and opening a bank account is a priority. Whether you are an expat, a digital nomad, or a retiree, understanding the banking landscape is crucial.

Why You Need a Local Account

While you can use foreign cards, a local account is often necessary for paying utility bills, receiving a salary from a Cypriot employer, or setting up internet services. It also helps in establishing a financial footprint if you plan to apply for credit later.

Required Documents

  • Passport or ID: Valid identification is mandatory.
  • Proof of Address: A utility bill (electricity or water) in your name. If you are renting, your rental agreement might be accepted, but often a bill is preferred.
  • Proof of Income: A payslip, letter from employer, or tax return if self-employed.
  • Reference Letter: Some banks may ask for a reference from your previous bank, known as a 'Bankers Reference'.

Top Banks in Cyprus

The two largest banks are Bank of Cyprus and Hellenic Bank. Both offer online banking apps, debit cards, and English-speaking support. Recently, digital alternatives like Revolut have become very popular, but having a traditional bank is still recommended for official processes.

Fees and Charges

Be aware that Cypriot banks often charge maintenance fees (around €2-5 per month) and fees for transfers. Always check the latest fee schedule before signing up.

The Application Process

Most banks require an appointment. Walk-ins are rare for account opening. Be prepared to spend 45-60 minutes at the branch signing various forms. Once approved, you will receive your IBAN immediately, but your card may take a few days to arrive by mail.

title: Work Permits and Employment in Cyprus
content:
Understanding Work Permits in Cyprus

Cyprus is an attractive destination for work, offering a pleasant climate and a growing economy. However, the requirements for working here legally depend significantly on your citizenship.

EU/EEA Citizens

If you are a citizen of an EU or EEA member state, you have the right to live and work in Cyprus without a work permit. However, if you plan to stay for more than 3 months, you must register with the Immigration Department and obtain a Registration Certificate (Yellow Slip). This process confirms your right to residency and employment.

Non-EU Citizens (Third Country Nationals)

For non-EU citizens, the process is stricter. You typically require a work permit before you can be employed. This permit is usually tied to a specific employer who must prove that the position cannot be filled by a local or EU candidate.

Types of Work Permits

  • General Employment: For specific sectors like agriculture or domestic work.
  • Creative Industry & Tech: Special schemes exist for high-skilled professionals in software and technology companies, often offering faster processing.
  • Companies of Foreign Interests: International companies registered in Cyprus can employ non-EU nationals more easily in key positions.

The Application Process

Your employer is generally responsible for submitting the application to the Department of Labour and the Civil Registry and Migration Department. You will need to provide a clear criminal record, medical test results, and a valid passport. The process can take several weeks or months.

Digital Nomad Visa

For remote workers earning income from outside Cyprus, the Digital Nomad Visa is a fantastic option. It allows you to reside in Cyprus while working for a foreign employer. You must prove a monthly income of at least €3,500 and have health insurance coverage.

title: Renting Property in Cyprus
content:
A Guide to Renting in Cyprus

Finding a rental property in Cyprus can be an exciting part of your relocation. From sea-view apartments in Limassol to traditional stone houses in Paphos, the options are diverse.

Popular Locations

  • Limassol: The business hub and most cosmopolitan city. Rents here are the highest, but you have access to the best jobs and nightlife.
  • Nicosia: The capital city. It offers a more authentic Cypriot lifestyle and is busy year-round, unlike some coastal resorts. Rents are generally lower than Limassol.
  • Paphos: Popular with expats and retirees. It offers a relaxed lifestyle and more affordable housing options.
  • Larnaca: A rising star with a new marina and promenade. Rents are reasonable, and it is close to the airport.

Rental Costs

As of 2024, a 1-bedroom apartment in Limassol might cost €1,000 - €1,500+, whereas in Paphos or Larnaca, you might find similar properties for €600 - €800. Utilities (electricity, water, internet) are usually extra.

The Rental Agreement

Standard leases are for one or two years. A deposit (equivalent to one or two months' rent) is standard. Ensure your contract is in English or translated so you understand the terms regarding notice periods and repairs. Always ask if 'common expenses' (building maintenance) are included in the rent.

Tips for Finding a Place

Use local websites like Bazaraki, but also walk around neighborhoods and look for 'To Rent' signs. Real estate agents are helpful but charge a commission (usually paid by the landlord). Beware of scams asking for deposits via money transfer before viewing the property.

title: Cyprus Income Tax Calculator & Guide
content:
Income Tax in Cyprus Explained

Cyprus has one of the most attractive tax systems in Europe, which is a major draw for expats and businesses. The personal income tax rates are progressive, but the tax-free threshold is generous.

Tax Rates (2025)

  • €0 - €19,500: 0% Tax
  • €19,501 - €28,000: 20% Tax
  • €28,001 - €36,300: 25% Tax
  • €36,301 - €60,000: 30% Tax
  • Over €60,000: 35% Tax

Social Insurance

In addition to income tax, employees contribute to the Social Insurance Fund (approx. 8.3%) and the General Healthcare System (GESY) (approx. 2.65%). These are deducted from your gross salary.

Exemptions for Expats

New residents taking up employment in Cyprus with a salary over €55,000 may be eligible for a 50% tax exemption on their employment income for a period of 17 years. This is a massive incentive for high earners.

Corporate Tax

The standard corporate tax rate is 12.5%, one of the lowest in the EU. This applies to net profits of companies resident in Cyprus.

Using a Tax Calculator

When using an online salary calculator, remember to input your gross monthly or annual salary. Deduct the social insurance and GESY contributions first to find your taxable income, then apply the tax brackets above. The net result is your take-home pay.

title: Cost of Living in Cyprus
content:
Is Cyprus Expensive?

The cost of living in Cyprus is generally lower than in Northern Europe (UK, Germany, Scandinavia) but has risen in recent years, particularly in housing. However, it offers a high quality of life for the price.

Breakdown of Expenses

Housing

Rent is the biggest expense. As mentioned in our Housing guide, Limassol is significantly more expensive than other cities. Electricity can also be costly, especially in summer due to air conditioning usage.

Food & Groceries

Local produce is affordable and high quality. Buying fruits and vegetables at local markets is cheaper than supermarkets. Imported goods are more expensive. Dining out is reasonable, with a meal at a local tavern costing €15-€20 per person.

Transport

Public transport is limited to buses, which are cheap (€1.50 per ride) but not always frequent. Most residents own a car. Petrol prices are generally slightly lower than the EU average. Car insurance and tax are quite affordable.

Healthcare

With the introduction of GESY (General Healthcare System), healthcare is very affordable for residents who contribute. Visits to a GP are often free or cost a nominal fee (€6), and medication is heavily subsidized.

Sample Monthly Budget (Single Person in Paphos)

  • Rent (1-bed): €700
  • Utilities: €120
  • Groceries: €250
  • Transport: €100
  • Entertainment: €150
  • Total: ~€1,320

title: Expat Communities & Resources
content:
Finding Your Community

Moving to a new country can be lonely, but Cyprus has a vibrant and welcoming expat community. English is widely spoken, making it easy to connect with others.

Online Groups

Facebook groups are the main hub for expat communication. Groups like 'Expats in Cyprus', 'Paphos Expats', or 'Limassol Community' are active daily with questions, event postings, and advice. They are a great place to ask for recommendations on plumbers, doctors, or schools.

Meetups and Events

Websites like Meetup.com often host social gatherings, hiking groups, or language exchange events. In Paphos and Limassol, you will find regular quiz nights, craft markets, and business networking events specifically for the international community.

Useful Apps & Websites

  • Bazaraki: The 'eBay of Cyprus' - use it to find cars, furniture, specialty items, and rentals.
  • Foody / Wolt: The main food delivery apps.
  • Cablenet / Primetel / Cyta: The main internet and mobile providers. Compare their packages online.

Emergency Numbers

Keep these handy:

  • 112: General Emergency (Police, Fire, Ambulance)
  • 1400: Hospital Information
  • 1460: Citizen's Line
